text:
I just finished making these and they are incredible!  I did make a few modifications though based on the recommendations of others and my personal taste.  I used 3 teaspoons of ginger, 1 1/2 teaspoons of cinnamon, and 1 teaspoon of cloves.  I also used dark brown sugar instead of white sugar and oj instead of water.  I used 1/2 cup butter and 1/4 cup margarine only because that is all I had.  I used a lot more white sugar to roll them in then the recipe called for, but I don't know how much I ended up using.  I did not have to flatten them at all.  I only baked them for 6 minutes (they were underbaked) and then after a couple of minutes, moved them to a wire rack.  The result is a delicious, chewy, spicy cookie!  I just wish I had made a double batch.  It made about 40 cookies (they weren't that big), but between us my husband and I ate 16 in one sitting!

text:
Amazing flavor and texture. But like others have noted, you MUST let the dough sit and harden at least 45 minutes. Preferably in the freezer. Not only does this make the dough easier to handle, but it will also prevent the finished cookies from deflating. I didn't let my first batch harden enough, and they ended up very flat and unappealing.   I also had to bake the full 10 minutes. At first I removed after 8, thinking the cookies would continue to cook. But they didn't, and ended up sticking (a lot) to the sheet. Those 2 minutes made all the difference, giving a beautiful appearance with nice edges and perfectly chewy and moist centers. I also threw in a cup of dried cranberries - complements the ginger really well.

I did need to very slightly pat down but if you squish the cookie it won't be as fluffy and will be a little more crunchy. Great cookies!!

These cookies are amazing. I read the other reviews and used the orange juice instead of water. I also used 1/4 cup brown sugar and 3/4 cup white sugar like someone else suggested. I feel like it makes it a little bit healthier. Even though it probably doesn't. I didn't have any margarine, so I just used real butter. I've read that it's not as sweet as the others, so maybe a little more sugar will be needed, but it has iron and other things that make these cookies a little healthier. Thank you for the great recipe. It will defenitely be a keeper in my family.

These were delicious. I followed other's suggestions and substituted orange juice (fresh from a navel orange) for the water in the recipe. It accented the flavor of the spices in the recipe, almost like a spicy soft version of a gingerbread cookie. I didn't chill the dough (as per other's recommendations) before forming it into balls and I didn't experience any of the flat cookies others were mentioning. Mine came out perfectly fluffy. I did add some finely chopped crystallized ginger that was hanging around my spice rack. It added a nice depth of flavor to these cookies. They were very good just rolled in sugar prior to baking. I think the glaze might have been a bit too much sugar. I may make a small amount and test it on one or two cookies. Maybe mix the powdered sugar with orange juice rather than water to carry through with the orange flavor? Regardless, very good and definitely on my list for holiday baking.

text:
I doubled the batch and did some experimenting with the dough.  First, I used butter instead of margarine and I added freshly grated nutmeg to the spice blend. Also, I used sorgham molasses but next time I will use straight molasses to get the "tang" and the "bite." The dough was managable without refrigeration BUT I did NOT roll into balls. I used a tablespoon to measure and scoop out the dough and I sprinkled raw sugar on the tops. This worked out GREAT and required no flattening. I was not able to finish the cookies in one night so I refrigerated the remaining dough until the next day. The dough was able to be rounded into balls but did not need flattening. Also, having the dough sit overnight in the refrigerated seemed to let the flavors marinate a bit as this batch was "spicier" than the batch I made the night before. My oven is old and has hot spots (good to know if you're a novice baker) so I baked the cookies for 4 minutes, turned the pan and continued for 3 minutes. They were slightly browned around the edges and set in the middle. I stored them in airtight containers and they stayed nice and soft. If you like ginger then you'll really like these. If you're not keen on autumn spices or molasses, you'll probably not like these. A great tip is to use molases/ sorgham molasses you REALLY REALLY like. If you can get the sticky stuff at a mill, do it. It's worth the effort for maximum flavor ;)

The cookies taste good, but the recipe needs to be clearer on 2 things.  The dough is unmanageable without being cooled a while.  We left it in the fridge for about an hour and it was easy to roll into balls after- otherwise it was mushy and sticky.  The other issue is the cooking time... I left the first tray in the oven 10 minutes and while they looked cooked, the cookies are so undercooked inside I could probably roll them into a ball of dough and start over.  The second batch was left in about 15 minutes and the cookies came out harder and crispier.  Next time I will go with 13 minutes and hope it will result in a soft cookie as described.

text:
what I like about this cookies is the texture. they are really soft unlike many hard ginger cookies I've eaten. I can't find molasses in my country so i use sub as allrecipes advice, brown sugar+cream of tartar but the color of my cookies is light unlike how the normal brown ginger cookies. This is a good cookie but lack the ginger taste that I expected. The next time I'm making this, I'm gonna double the ginger and cinnamon. Nevertheless, a good recipe! #UPDATE# I had half of this batter in the freezer, so this time baking them, i rolled the balls in a 1/3cup brown sugar+/1/2tsp ginger powder + 1/2 tsp ground cinnamon. This way, the ginger taste and aroma is intensified and they are so delicious!

text:
wow - i really don't understand how one recipe can result in so many different results!  most reviewers who gave a lower rating complained that the cookies flattened too much.  this is usually from using too much butter in a recipe or not enough flour.  i found that this recipe had so much flour that i had to use my hands just to mix it all in.  good thing is that the more flour you pack in a cookie, the softer it will turn out.  problem was that these did not flatten out AT ALL.  it was very crumbly to shape into balls (takes a whole afternoon if you double the recipe!) and came out of the oven as balls.  second batch in oven i flattened completely with the bottom of a glass.  problem with that is that they are not that incredibly tasty... a mild spice and just kind of there.  because i doubled the recipe and have a ton of dough and kids anxious to have good cookies for the weekend, i will ice these babies with a brown sugar icing or an orange icing.  that should salvage them enough.  i just can't believe this recipe gets a full five stars when 1600 people have tried it!  i can only assume that these people have not ever tried REALLY good cookies LOL.

text:
They aren't the best that I've ever tasted, but they're definitely an impressive homemade cookie to serve. 

For me, the chewiness and ginger flavor were the most important. When I first tasted the batter, I also thought the molasses was overwhelming. I added more ginger and more salt. I also added vanilla extract and a tablespoon of milk to give a little extra "lift." 

I refrigerated the dough in a covered bowl for about two hours before forming into balls with a spoon. 

Instead of just sugar, I rolled the dough balls in a mixture of sugar, a little salt, some ginger and allspice. I did not flatten the balls before baking. 

I started off with small cookies baked for 8 minutes, but found the best chewiness with large cookies baked for 10 minutes. Since gingerbread cookies are so fickle, you might want to do some trial and error with your oven to figure out how long to bake to get the desired consistency.

text:
As the other posters have said, these are great cookies!  I followed another poster's advice and used orange juice instead of the water....am mulling over using coffee next time just to see what happens.   The only other things I did was throw in a few tablespoons of brown sugar--only because I was nearly out of regular sugar--and I put in some extra ginger because we love that 'bite'.

Also, I flattened the first cookies and then tried baking them without flattening them out, and I think I like the non-flattened ones better.

To repeat what other posters have said, put your dough in the fridge for 30 minutes or so...makes a world of difference in working with them.

I'll definitely be baking these again!!

text:
I am just finishing up baking these, and they are very tasty! They have a spicy sweet flavor. I followed the recipe almost to a T, here are the few slight changes I made:
1) I added a dash of dried ground orange peel
2) I didn't have any cloves, and don't really enjoy their flavor, so I replaced them with nutmeg
3)I used butter rather than margarine
4) I didn't roll them in sugar

The flavor of these is very nice, not too sweet not too spicy. They are very festive for fall/winter and will go great with some apple cider! The only thing that was bad about this cookie was how hard to handle the dough is. I put it in the freezer for about 30min and it was still very very sticky and hard to work with. I had to flour my hands between every cookie ball. I also found it unnecessary to press the cookie balls down because they spread a lot while cooking. Next time I make this I may add a pinch more baking soda so that they don't end up so flat.

text:
excellent.  I used butter for margarine, fresh mandarin juice for water, and fresh grated ginger for ground dried ginger.  Then I doubled the recipe.  I baked half the dough tonight and am letting the other half rest for fresh cookies tomorrow.  

The neighbors who shared these with me tonight suggested I quit my day job!  The butter flavour comes through nicely.


EDIT!

I am still making this recipe, and have some suggestions:

If the cookies are not soft and 'fluffy' enough, let the dough rest over night in the fridge, and don't let it warm up too much before it gets to the oven.  

if you like it 'gingery' add a half a table spoon of freshly grated ginger root and a half teaspoon of cardamom

use dark molassas if you like it a bit more...molassassy??  

I have not found any problem with them flattening out, as others have described... perhaps it is the butter?

again, excellent recipe

Cant stop eating these wonderful cookies. Baked them this afternoon, got 46 walnut sized before baking. If I stayed out of the cookie dough I am sure I would have gotten 48 cookies. Hubby and I both think these are great cookies. I had to use Crisco Butter Flavor shortening instead of butter. I added 1 tsp Cinnamon.Note to all: I sifted the 2 1/4 cups flour before I measured it out for the recipe, then added the remaining dry spices etc. I rolled them in Turbinado Sugar,(a light brown sugar noticeably coarse. The dough was soft and with my Pampered Chef small cookie scoop the dough was just fine. I scooped and dropped into the sugar,(about 1/2 cup) rolled slightly with my fingers and lifted them to the airbake cookie sheet. 20 dough balls fit onto a sheet with just enough room to spread.They spread to about a 3" cookie. Exactly 10 min cooking for my convection oven. Perfect. Mine flattened out all on there own, and are crisp on the outside and chewy on the inside, and cracked tops....a very perfect cookie.

text:
You'll definitely want to make 2 batches of this stuff because it goes quickly!

I made this recipe two ways:  I accidently used 1 stick of butter instead of a full 3/4 cups for the first batch. The second batch I followed the recipe exactly. The batch with less butter yielded a slightly more cakelike texture. After an hour of refrigeration, I made half of the dough into rolled balls and used the other half to cut out gingerbread men. Both turned out great. For personal preferences, I had to skip the step of rolling the balls into sugar, however. I preferred them without it because I didn't like the extra crunch. It wasn't real crunchy, but it was enough to seem weird to me for some reason. The cookies didn't need the extra sweetness either.

Other notes: I pressed the cookies down to 1/4" thick, and returned the dough to the refrigerator until I was ready to make another batch for the oven. The process went simply!

The taste IS excellent.  I was able to roll them into perfect balls by chilling them in the freezer a few hours before dropping them in a ziplock filled with sugar and shaking.  HOWEVER, despite the taste, they take a long time to make and they are VERY difficult to judge when they're done (the first batch burned the bottoms slightly and so I took them out earlier the next time to find them still soft in the middle.  Hard to find a happy medium.  Fortunately I was able to cut off the bottoms with nary a blemish so they still look as good as they taste.  But for those reasons I only give them four stars..

These taste delicious! Based on other people's reviews and my personal taste, I made the below changes:
- Sub OJ for water
- Sub brown sugar for white
- Changed spices to 1tsp of cinnamon and nutmeg. Kept the ginger at 2tsp
- put the dough in the fridge for a few hours
- Rolled in cinnamon sugar
Needed to bake for the full 10 mins to make sure the cookie was fully cooked. So Yum!

text:
Ok so these cookies smell and taste amazing. However, I had several issues with them. I followed others’ advice and flattened the cookies, and they came out paper thin. Then I baked another batch and only flattened them a little, and they look exactly like the first batch, paper thin. So for the third batch I’ve made, I substituted butter flavored shortening for the butter,and I did not flatten these at all and they finally resemble normal cookies. Not sure if anyone else has had this problem. All batches tasted great but the third batch with shortening are much more aesthetically pleasing :)

Excellent Cookie!  Not too sweet, and a nice warm spice  that stays on the tongue. I read the other reviews and opted to use brown sugar instead of white, orange juice instead of water, and chilled the dough for about an hour before attempting to roll them. I added the flour to the sugar mixture a little at a time and stirred it in each time by hand starting with a whisk and then switching to a wooden spoon when the dough got a little thicker.  This made the dough very easy to work with and not too sticky.  The stickiest parts were those that had stuck to the bowl.  Also, I replaced the margarine with butter.  They came out very good and are delicious.

I've been making these for  a couple of years now. We prefer spicier, moister and fuller-flavoured cookies, so I replace 1/2 of the white sugar with Demerara sugar, increase molasses to 1/3 cup, cloves to 1 tsp, cinnamon to 2 tsp and ginger to 3 tsp and increase the size of each cookie. My family loves making these larger soft cookies into ice cream sandwiches by 'squishing' vanilla ice cream between 2 cookies while they are still warm from the oven

text:
These are the best cookies ever! They are very soft and delicious. I use butter instead of margarine. My family loves them. Sometimes I make three dozen smaller cookies instead of two dozen, to make them last longer. Either way, they are really good. The first few times I made them, I had trouble with the dough being sticky, and had to let the dough sit a while, but now I don't have a problem with it. I use two spoons to drop a ball of dough into a bowl of sugar, and then roll it around, touching only the part that actually has sugar on it (after the dough touches the sugar it doesn't stick). I would advise baking the cookies for at least ten minutes so they don't end up doughy in the middle. Don't bake them too long, though, or they will get chewy. These cookies are perfect for Christmas, although I make them all through the year.

text:
This has been my go-to cookie recipe for some time now - one of the few things I've ever baked that ALL three of my kids will eat - A miracle!!! The cookie dough was a bit awkward to handle initially.  I also found that timing needed to be quite precise - baking for a minute above or below the correct time would leave me with ether too crispy or too soggy a cookie.  Having made them so many times now though, I have settled into a system I'm happy with and which seems to turn out cookies just like those in the picture:  

1) I pre-heat the oven to the stated temperature then prepare the cookie dough exactly as set out in the recipe - though a little extra spice sometimes makes its way into the mix. 
2)  As suggested by others, once ready I place the dough in the refrigerator to firm up.
3)  Before committing a whole tray of dough balls to the oven I do a test bake with a single one to fine-tune my timings.  The ball itself I form by scooping out 1 Tablespoon of the dough, gently rolling it into a ball with my hands then placing it on the baking tray.  I don't flatten the ball, and sprinkle sugar over it before placing the tray in the oven.  I set my timer and immediately break open the cookie once done to see how the inside  looks.  It gets gobbled down regardless and I adjust my cooking time based on how over-under cooked it appeared.  Only then do I commit to putting whole trays of cookie dough in the oven – all prepared the same way as above.    

In the past I tried playin

text:
LOWER CALORIE, LOWER FAT VERSION: I modified this recipe to make it lower fat & lower calorie. Instead of 3/4 cup margarine, I used 1/4 cup vegetable oil and 1/2 cup unsweetened applesauce. I used 1 cup Truvia in place of 1 cup sugar. I also added an extra egg white to the recipe on top of the one whole egg (thinking it might make it more cake-like). The batter ended up pretty sticky/wet, so I added another 1/4 flour, and I had to spoon the batter onto the cookie sheet. The cookies puffed up nicely and did not flatten out too much. They came out soft and moist, and the applesauce added a nice hint of apples/fall flavor. They came out very sweet, so I might cut back on the applesauce a little next time. Also, with less oil, they left a very thin film under the cookies when I peeled them off, so you may want to lightly grease the sheet, but I was OK with the very thin film of cookie it left behind. I am not a cook, and this was a first attempt in many years at "baked goods", but I'm pleased with the recipe, and will make them again! In an effort to get away from processed foods, I'm thrilled that these were easy, quick, and healthier than store bought!

text:
These cookies were delicious! I wanted to make real gingerbread men and this is what I did to make it work: Placed cookie dough in fridge for 20 minutes (to make easier to work with), after that I put a piece of wax paper onto my working surface, sprinkled generously with flour, placed a portion of cookie dough onto paper and sprinkled generously with flour then place another piece of wax paper on top then I rolled out flat to cut out gingerbread men. I ended up making then very thin, not on purpose, but I loved it. I used the Royal Icing II recipe to decorate these cookies. I am new to cookie cutting and using royal icing - this all took a lot of time but I would do it again because the cookies were a major hit!

text:
A great recipe! I doubled the recipe for an office cookie exchange, and made a few changes (listed below, for the doubled recipe)
1 1/2 tsp fresh ground or grated ginger
An additional egg white
A few tablespoons more flour.
I would have used 2 - 2 1/2 tsp of ginger, and a whole egg extra. The flour is just to balance the extra wet ingredients. The dough is very delicate - I let my dough chill in the fridge for about 45 minutes, but that wasn't enough to chill the whole batch. Two hours is probably enough. 
This probably could be turned into gingerbread mini cupcakes by simply scooping the dough into a room temp pan and baking them.
It's been almost a week since I made them, and they are still soft and melt In your mouth tender. Will make again.

text:
Love these, and always double the batch - they won't go to waste!  Couple tips:  1) Instead of "shaping dough into walnut sized balls," use a small ice cream scooper to scoop balls directly into the bowl of sugar - much cleaner that way, and all the cookies turn out the same  size.  Yummy!!  2) I never use the prescribed 2 T of sugar for rolling the balls....I just put about 1/2-1 cup of sugar in a bowl and roll away...then toss the remaining sugar.  Having a little more makes that part go a little faster/easier.  3) Finally, if your molasses is running low (I used up the last of ours), put the bottle in the microwave for 10-20 seconds and the remaining amount stuck to the bottom will pour our more easily.  Also...use the tip by other reviewer - spray your measuring cup with cooking spray before measuring the molasses into your cookie dough mix...makes it MUCH easier to get it all out.

We did three batches at once... I think I would recommend doing one or maybe two, batch at a time to give you a little time in between batches unless you have an assembly line going, lol! But we did okay and most of them turned out great! I also recommend NOT smoothing them down too far once they are on the cookie sheet. Leave them a little plump so they will be a little thicker. And err on the side of smaller if you're going to err at all... The bigger the ball, the flatter cookie, or so it seemed with ours. All in all, though, we had a good first run!

I made this today for the first time and they turned out perfect and soft and delicious! I tweaked it (of course) - by adding 2 tsp of cornstarch, used 1 tsp of fresh grated ginger (added to the wet mix) and 1 tsp ground dry ginger (in the dry mix), used allspice instead of cloves, 1/2 c. Earth balance and 1/4 c. of sunflower oil, and used 90 ml of brown sugar and 90 ml of white sugar (total of 3/4 cup of sugar - not as potent as a full cup!), I used 1 tbsp. of orange juice as suggested in the comments and used egg replacer since I can't eat eggs. This turned out amazing! I will be making this more often.

text:
These were pretty good! I've made them 3 times, every time with butter:
1) I made as directed and they were sticky and way too sweet! I had rolled them in sugar. I had chilled them as other people had suggested and didn't really think it had an effect. They were hard as rocks after baking so I had them dipped in my tea. They had excellent flavour though, so I knew I was going to make them again with some alterations.
2) I reduced the sugar to 3/4 cup of sugar and omitted the water. Tasted delicious and were softer! But didn't really flatten out or crinkle nicely around the edges. I didn't chill them this time. Also had the oven at 375
3) I kept the sugar at 3/4 cups, still left out the water, but added slightly more butter, Like 7/8ths of a cup. Oven at 375. I rolled them about 1.5 inch balls and did not flatten. Still didn't chill and this time they are perfect! Is definitely a keeper now that I have perfected the recipe!

text:
Great texture (light and fluffy) but bland. This is what I did differently from the recipe: 
I used 1 stick of butter plus 4 TBSP margarine
I used 5 TBSP very dark homemade brown sugar (instead of molasses)
I used 1 TBSP orange juice (instead of water)
Perfect baking time for me was: 9 minutes

The result was a great non-sticky cookie dough that was easy to roll into balls without refrigeration. The first six cookies were very light in color (not a gingerbread look at all) and rose well as they baked. The cookies were uniform, soft, and fluffy when they were done baking. However, the cookies tasted like bland sugar cookies with just a hint of spice at the end.

So, working with the remaining dough, I sprinkled an additional 2 tsp of ginger powder, 1 tsp of cinnamon and drizzled about 1/2 TBSP of molasses on top. I mixed the dough with my hands (too lazy to drag out the mixer again). I baked the cookies for 9 minutes. This time, the cookies turned out darker with more spice. The texture is still slightly soft but firmer. The cookies were still lacking that full-on gingerbread taste.

I will make this recipe again but I will let the dough rest in the fridge for a day, wrapped in plastic wrap, to let the spices meld.

text:
Delicious! But it took me 4 times to figure out how to get the cookie I wanted (all using the same batch of dough) I used butter instead of margarine and increased the ground cloves to 1 teaspoon. I also combined everything in one bowl, combining wet ingredients first and then adding the dry so as to not have too much clean up. I then let it cool in the freezer for 30 minutes so the dough was easier to work with. 

I wanted a very specific looking cookie when I found this recipe - I wanted huge cookies with cracked tops. This is what I learned from the 4 batches I made - gently flatten with your finger tips if you want cracked tops - don't use the bottom of a glass. The more free air incorporated into the dough will help with cracking and using the bottom of a glass took too much of the air out of the dough. I also think that if you add a few small separate pieces of dough to the top of the cookie and just tap them on top - you will increase your chances of cracks.  If you want big cookies - use a lot more than a walnut size as instructed. For my big cookies the dough ball was closer to a ping-pong ball in size. I flattened gently with my finger tips until they were approximately 2 inches in diameter and about 1/3-inch high. I did not dip in sugar. I upped the oven temperature to 380 degrees and baked for 9 minutes. I uploaded a picture showing all 4 batches I made - the 4th batch was the winner as far as looks go - but they all taste great!

text:
Loathing the dry grocery-store ginger snaps always around the house when I was young, I thought I hated ginger cookies... Until this recipe. These cookies are soft and chewy and have an absolute exquisite balance of flavors. As others have said, though, it's good to let the dough chill for awhile otherwise getting them on the cookie sheet is a HUGE mess. I bet they'd bake the same with dough at room temperature but if you can spare yourself the fuss, why not? A hard lesson for me with this recipe is to watch them very, very closely in the oven... there's less than a minute between perfect and inedibly hard, and the difference is very subtle. You'll have to start pulling them out and giving them a good look every minute or so toward the end of baking. If you time it right, though, these are pretty much the best thing ever.

text:
I rated this 4 but these were so unbelievably amazing the way I made them. We ended up making 3 batches! I used 2 1/2 cups of ap flour, 1 1/2 tsp of baking soda, 2 tsp of cinnamon, no cloves, 1/2 cup brown sugar INSTEAD of molasses, 1 TB vanilla INSTEAD of water, and a lot more ginger like 4 tsp of ground ginger and OVER a TB of grated fresh ginger root. I dropped the balls into brown sugar and flattened slightly I also used parchment paper for no fuss removal and easy cleanup and I sprayed my hands w/ cooking spray before rolling so I didn't have to put the dough in the fridge.  My family was eating them faster than I could bake them, I should have just doubled the recipe to begin w/. This is my new go-to cookie and I will always make these everytime I go anywhere and need to bring food. Ginger is so beneficial I doubt we will get it any other way than this. I just hate how I cant stop!:)

text:
soft cookie, good, mild flavor. followed recipe. no changes.
Used cold soft tub margarine, and warmed my molassess up in the microwave so it was runny (makes it not sticky). rolled nicely right after mixing. no chilling. cooked 10 minutes. the cookies still looked soft and runny on top at 10 minutes, but after closer inspection the bottoms were starting to look a bit darker than the rest of the cookie and I could smell them. both good signs a cookie is done. I took them out fearing they were not cooked properly, and let them sit on the cookie sheet for 5 minutes. The tops firmed up while sitting and volia! a perfect soft cookie.

made 3/4 inch balls - not flattened  only flattened slightly for a fluffy small cookie.
made 1.5 inch balls flattened half way - turned out about the same as they went in.

text:
These are very good cookies.. as a preparation tip, chilling the batter helps alot with the rolling process, but I've found that the most efficient, and cleanest way to sugar the cookies is to use a disher and dish the cookies straight into a cereal sized bowl with the sugar in it.  Toss the dough ball in the sugar bowl as you would if you were sauteeing or flipping a pancake.  This way, your hands don't even touch the batter until it's covered in sugar - way easier to maneuver to the pan.  Oh!  And they are on the puffier side when you first take them out of the oven, but the 5 minute cooling time on the pan is crucial to letting them "deflate" into what looks like the picture

1/2 cup unsalted butter, softened;
1/3 cup shortening;
1 teaspoon vanilla extract;
3 tablespoons milk;
2 Tablespoons, 1 teaspoon lemon juice;
4 cups powdered sugar

This is one yummy cookie!  Hubby was in the mood for gingerbread, so I made these.  I did use all butter...never have marjarine, and because I had only about 3/4 cup sugar, used dark brown sugar for the remaining 1/4 cup.  After refrigerating the dough for about 45 minutes, they were easy to work with.  I didn't roll them in sugar, and thought they were just sweet enough as is.  I used my 1 tablespoon cookie scoop.  They turned out chewy with a slightly crisp outer edge.  Hubs can't stop eating them!  I ended up with 28 cookies.  These are going on my Christmas cookie trays for sure.  Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
I first made these cookies a couple years ago and nearly ate myself sick! I've now made them for the second time tonight and they are every bit as delicious. Some tweaks I make with this recipe are: 1 T of orange juice instead of water, use 1/2 tsp baking soda and 1/2 tsp baking powder, and add more spices than called for (especially cloves, LOVE cloves). Finally, I sub out 1 c dark brown sugar instead of white, as I love the beautiful dark, molasses color I think ginger cookies should be. I've tried the balls vs. flattening them and honestly don't notice much of a difference, so I generally just shape them into balls and roll them in sugar. 8 minutes in my oven is perfect and these cookies deliver exactly the texture I love in all cookies....soft and chewy on the inside and just slightly crispy on the outside. I adore the smell of these cookies as I'm taking them out of the oven. They make my kitchen smell divine. LOVE this recipe!

All I can say is WOOOOOOW!!! These cookies are D-E-LICIOUS. I made these for my friends at small group and the girls loved it!! All the cookies were gone within 30 minutes(no joke). text:
If you like ginger cookies, you'll LOVE this recipe and if you don't like ginger cookies, this may be the recipe that changes your mind.  I followed the recipe exactly, except for a repeated suggestion from many reviews, to substitute orange juice for the water.  By rolling the uncooked ball of dough in sugar, it produces a crackly exterior that seems to really highlight the soft and chewy interior.  I also opted to make a simple glaze of powdered sugar and milk, which I drizzled over the cooled cookie.  Perfect.  This will be integrated into my Christmas cookie lineup.

I live in Western Canada. After trying to make these a few times and having them fall flat and crispy on me I have found that putting the formed balls into the fridge for 1/2 an hour then directly transferring them into the pre-heated oven works nicely. They are soft in the center as the recipe states. I also tried a chocolate ginger cookie recipe once it having chocolate chips in it gave me the idea of putting a tbsp of cacao powder ( pure cocoa pwdr) in the flour mixture of these cookies. I love the result. Now I can rate this a 5 star recipe.

The BEST EVER! I've made numerous ginger molassas cookies before and somehow none as good as these.   I made these with my two girls ages 7 and 5.  We measured everything exactly as it was called for. ( I am one for following a recipe to the letter the first time I make it). Thanks for sharing.  This is a keeper!!!

Yummy!

I used gluten-free flour (so added 1 tsp xanthan gum), didn't have any cloves (so added nutmeg), and used half cup honey/half cup sugar (instead of 1 cup sugar). Put dough in the fridge for almost an hour before rolling into balls. Rolled in raw (chunky brown) sugar (probably closer to 4-5 tablespoons). Cooked one batch for 8 minutes and one batch for 9 minutes. I think 9 minutes is better.

Cookies are delicious! Great recipe. EASY! Delicious. Love it! Love it! Love it! Thank you!

Amazing Recipe! Very easy. Beware that the dough is very sticky. I put it in the fridge for a while to make it easier to roll into balls. The more you flatten them, the hard they'll be. If you want a soft cookie, don't flatten it very much. Hard cookie (good for dipping in milk) flatten quite a bit.

OH MY GOODNESS, these are SO good!  I will never make another ginger/molasses cookie again.  I have made them multiple times and my family loves them.  I have a hard time not eating at least six right off the countertop. I did double all spices as I like my molasses cookies with a little kick.  I also rolled them in nutmeg sugar prior to baking.  They didn't spread out too much (i.e., remained thick) and they STAY SOFT!  They will be part of my Christmas baking for sure.

Made these, turned out great! Used a whisk instead of sifting each ingredient, which worked nicely. I took other reviewers' advice and used orange juice instead of water. text:
These are good cookies, but in the interest of full disclosure, I've only ever had store-bought gingersnap cookies that are like rocks.   I used white whole wheat flour and I scooped it out of the canister (instead of spooning it in and leveling it off) to try and make sure that my dough wasn't too sticky. I also heaped the ginger, cinnamon and baking soda before adding them. I used half brown and half white sugar, put in Cointreau instead of the water, and used butter instead of margarine. Finally, I rolled the cookies in cinnamon sugar before baking them for 8 minutes. With all those changes my cookies turned out just fine, very soft with a nice little crunch from the sugar. I had a few cookies that had some cracks but none looked like the main picture, maybe I just need a good food stylist.

I've made them a number of times and they are always a hit!

text:
These were great cookies. Don't forget to flatten the cookies, because they won't really do it themselves. I didn't have mace, so I used a little nutmeg and allspice (about 1/8 teaspoon of each) as a replacement. Be sure to measure your spices accurately, because if you don't you'll get cookies with too strong a flavor. I wanted butter, so I used half shortening and half butter. I melted the butter before to make sure the cookie stayed chewy. Instead of the 1 cup of white sugar, I used about 1/2 cup white sugar, 1/4 cup brown sugar and added some honey to the recipe.

text:
I was not sure if these would work out since there were several 1-star horror stories, but they are near perfect (no crackled top like the picture).  I used 1c all-purpose and 1 1/4c whole wheat, used 1T oj in place of the called for water, an additional 2T water since I was using whole wheat, used 2/3 c of sugar as suggested by another reivewer, and baked for exactly 10 min.  I rolled 18 balls (the remaining 6 were probably stuck to my hands), rolled in sugar, and lightly pressed down.  They did expand and baked flat (not baked cookie balls like another reviewer).  Like another reivewr, even after reducing the sugar the cookies were still too sweet.  Next time I will use 1/2c sugar instead-- rolling in sugar adds a lot of sweetness already, and try fresh ginger.  Thanks for the recipe. How do you get the cookie to crackle??

text:
I make these cookies every Christmas season! Theyre amazing and sooooo yummy.  I keep ALL of the ingredients exactly the same but refridgerate the dough for up to 3 hours to really get it nice and firm since it is a very soft and ticky dough. Ive read reviews where people used butter instead of margarine, Ive made this mistake once before also..after all isnt butter better? Well not for these cookies! Think about butter and margarine in their cold refridgerated state, margarine is soft and butter is hard-hence the super soft sticky dough and why chilling dough is very helpful. The margarine, I think helps to lend to the soft chewiness of the cookie, while the butter makes them more on the crispy, crunchy side. 
I also use a cookie scooper for even sized cookies and I als flatten the rounds of dogh slightly before baking.  These are truley amazing, a a must-try even if you dont like ginger or molasses!

text:
The only alterations I made to these were using 1/3 cup Brown Sugar with 2/3 White Sugar and 1/4 cup Butter with 1/2 cup Margarine and placed the dough in the fridge for 20 minutes (I made these alterations by preference and reviews).  When shaping the dough I flattened them a bit before 'flipping' them in sugar so they would be wide and they turned out fabulous!  There's no airtight jar needed!  They might feel hard outside when a day old (if they last that long) but they melt in your mouth!!  Some might say they are too sweet but the sugar is a great contrast to the mild yet flavorful spices.

text:
These are great cookies! The only thing I have to complain is that the dough is very, very sticky and that makes it difficult to form the "walnut-sized balls". MY TIP: put the dough in the fridge for 5-10 minutes before forming the balls; it won't stick to you as easily and the dough is much easier to work with. AND: instead of rolling the dough balls IN the sugar; just sprinkle it on the dough before it goes into the oven and it will cut down on the sweetness. All in all a very good cookie.

These were delicious, and the aroma was heavenly!  They were very moist and chewy.  I didn't change the spices, but they were almost perfect.  I will add a bit more cinnamon next time.  I liked that these didn't have too strong of a spicy or molasses flavor.  I did use OJ instead of water.  My only problem with the recipe is that my cookies spread so much that they were very thin and flat.  I am positively ANAL when it comes to measuring (I level the flour with a straight edge, etc.), so I know it wasn't anything I did.  I think a little more flour (about 1/4 C) might do the trick.  Or, possibly a little less sugar.  It would also be nice to find some coarse sugar to roll them in for an even prettier presentation.  Next time, I will definitely double the recipe, because they didn't last long!

Not bad at all.  The cloves weren't overwhelming for me as some reviewers complained, but I really like spicy gingerbread cookies.  I swapped spiced rum for the water, which I really enjoyed.  The flavor of these cookies was excellent, and the texture was nice and soft.  I flattened them a bit as instructed, and they came out of the oven absolutely beautiful, but they flattened quite a bit while cooling - as flat as a ginger snap, though they somehow maintained their softness.  Odd.  I'll likely make these again, but I'd love to figure out how to make them less flat.  I don't want "dough balls" as other reviewers complained of, but I'd like something with a little volume.  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
When I used this recipe, the dough turned out messy and the cookies ended up tasty, but flat and very crumbly.  I made a new batch, this time using 3/4 cup olive oil (light flavor works best) instead of butter and only a little bit of orange juice instead of the 1 Tbsp water. Everything else was the same.   The dough was so much easier to roll into balls - I made mine walnut sized - and they came out perfectly crispy on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside. Yum!

text:
These cookies are dangerous!  You will want to make these again and again.  Doubling the recipe also works well ;) I tried the orange juice substitution for H2O once but I didn't notice any difference.  I used butter instead of margarine since I never use margarine. I put the mixture in the freezer for about a half hour, as suggested by other users.  This really helps with forming the dough into balls.  I use one of those cookie dough scoops.   I've added crystallized ginger (probably about 1/4 cup chopped) to the mixture and also little bits to the tops before baking (squish em down into the top).  This is quite nice if you like crystallized ginger.

text:
Followed the recipe exactly.  Turned out perfect and stayed soft for days.  Made 3 times and everyone that has one wants the recipe! I read reviews that said the dough was too gooey or runny.  One of the 3 times I made these, the dough was very gooey, DO NOT OVER SOFTEN THE BUTTER! If you do over soften the butter, just throw the dough in the fridge to cool and the dough will become firmer.  Once again, DO NOT OVER SOFTEN THE BUTTER!  Soften enough to mix, do not melt it down. LOVE LOVE THE RECIPE, don't change a thing!

I consider my cooking abilities to be better than average, but I have very little experience baking. I just made these cookies and they turned out AMAZING!!! Great recipe, thank you for posting it!! I made a frosting and drizzled it over the cookies once they had cooled which gave them a little finishing touch. (The frosting I whipped up was about 1 cup of powdered sugar, 1/2 teaspoon Vanilla extract, 1 Tablespoon of softened margarine, and then slowly add enough milk while whisking until the mixture turns to a frosting consistency. Too thin - add more powdered sugar. Too thick and clumpy - add more milk.)

text:
I made 12 dozen of these and everyone has raved about them!  I used butter instead of margarine and OJ instead of water.  As other reviewers recommended, chilling the dough an hour before shaping really helped.  I coated the tops only with sugar and pressed the balls very flat using a drinking glass dipped in sugar (to prevent sticking).  After they cooled I decorated them with white cookie decorating icing (the tube says "stackable," but don't stack unless you use wax paper - they'll stick to the icing below). I made snowflake designs and gave them away as gifts - beautiful and delicious!  Will make again every Christmas.

text:
Wonderful ginger cookie recipe! While the recipe's spice combination is great, I also added some nutmeg and allspice to the mix. I used whole-wheat flour and they still came out great. I would recommend chilling the dough for at least an hour as it is really sticky to work with. I rolled them into balls, dipped my fingers in sugar, and pressed the balls flat. I baked them for a little over 10 minutes, and they were soft in the middle and slightly crunchy on the outside. This one's a keeper!

text:
These cookies are wonderful!  I added lemon juice instead of water and 1 Tablespoon of crystallized ginger.  I didn't bother flattening them.  They ended up flattening after I took them out of the oven.  Since I enjoy lemon ginger cookies, I decided to try a lemon glaze (1 3/4 c. powdered sugar, 2 Tablespoons melted butter, and 1/4 c. lemon juice).  They were wonderful with the glaze as well.  But if you enjoy gingersnaps, they are just perfect without the glaze.  A family favorite that we will definitely make again!

text:
These cookies are fabulous! Ginger things are not usually my cup of tea, but I was looking for something that was out of the usual "chocolate chip/sugar/peanut butter" range. I'm so glad I decided to make these! Though they came out flatter than I thought they would, they're the perfect sweet and spicy holiday cookie. I slightly increased the spices and only had to bake for 8 minutes. (8 minutes gave me a soft cookie with a chewy outside, 9 minutes chewy all the way through.) I put my dough into the freezer while I mixed dough for other cookies I was making and so didn't have a problem with rolling. I feel that the sugar for rolling wasn't necessary but it does make the end product sparkle prettily, so I may just cut the sugar in the dough next time I make these (and there WILL be a next time!) A lot of reviewers subbed OJ for the water and I didn't have any, so I used 2 tsp of water and 1 tsp of orange extract. Yum!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of the first and most tried and true cookie recipes on this website but I've made some modifications that I think will make this recipe even better! (see below). I've baked them before and was told that I put some kind of addictive drug in them. The only tricky thing about making these cookies is the rolling into a ball part. If you use margarine, your dough can be a bit too gooey to roll. I've added more flour, chilled the dough, neither really works well. Here's what I do, sub 1/4 cup of the margarine with butter. This makes it easy to form the dough. It's still sticky but the ball forms fine. I wouldn't use all butter because then the cookie gets too crispy and doesn't stay as soft. I also don't roll the dough in sugar at the end. I think the cookie has enough.
Edit: The last time I made these, I entered them in a cookie contest and lost (the cookies look deceptively plain)! THIS year I'm taking these cookies to the next level by adding: crushed pecans, dried cranberries, and orange rind (also subing fresh squeezed OJ for water) and they came out great! I hope I win the contest this year! I call these cookies GPCs for Ginger Pecan Cranberry.

text:
Can't say enough good things about this recipe. They're easy to throw together and they come out perfect. Since I live in NM, I added 1/4 tsp red chili powder (because we put chili in everything) to the batter to give the spices a little more heat. I'd suggest 1/16-1/8 tsp for those who don't like much heat but want to enhance the spices a bit. I also cut the sugar in half, but they still came out sweet enough. These puff and spread a bit so this recipe isn't the best for cutouts, but it's -awesome- if you want a simple cookie.

Yummy!!!  I am not a huge fan of "spice" cookies and don't typically like things with cloves, but, this cookie was great!   The combination of molasses, cloves and all of that ginger was wonderful. I did use orange juice in place of the water as many reviewers suggested.  I accidently used baking powder instead of baking soda (a common mistake of mine - when will I learn??). Definitely try this recipe!

text:
Definitely an excellent cookie. I followed the recipe exactly except that I had to use butter instead of margarine as that was what was on hand. My husband thanked me several times for making them for him. I usually have all these ingredients so I will be making them often. The only problem I can see is, there are too few cookies! Lol.
Big Hint. Those who are having trouble with the dough being too moist will benefit by knowing that after the egg is mixed in the electric mixer, do not use the mixer. The instructions say to stir in the rest of the ingredients. The texture will be much easier to shape into balls. No refrigeration is needed.
My 3 year old grandson told me to keep making them so we don't run out.

Love these cookies! Based on other reviews, I used butter instead of margarine and I added 1/4 cup of extra flour. My trick for this type of cookie (like Snickerdoodles) is to use a small cookie scoop to drop the dough directly into a small bowl with sugar in it, then swirl the dough around in the bowl to coat. You won't get your fingers sticky.

text:
These cookies are very close to my neighborhood bakery's ginger molasses cookies (which I still think are the best).  I used full-bodied molasses, which gave it a richer color and taste.  Even cutting back on the butter (to 1/2 cup) and sugar, the cookies turned out very moist, soft, chewy, and sweet, baking for 8 mins on the dot.  I actually would put more ginger in next time.  In my batch I made them extra decadent by adding in chopped dark chocolate-covered candied ginger from trader joe's... really rich and yummy!  I'm sure it would be great with just chopped candied ginger, or plain, as it is in the recipe.  Sometimes I'm in a mood for a crispier cookie so one pan I made the cookies smaller and baked them for a full 10 mins - they turned out like gingersnaps!!  YUM!  Fantastic how one recipe can give you big, soft, chewy ginger cookies and also crunchy, crispy gingersnaps!

text:
These are yummy.  After reading some of the earlier posts, I did increase the flour to a generous 2 1/2 cups and had no problems with sticky dough.  I also followed the advice of others and reduced cloves to 1/4 tsp. and used 1/2 cup butter (vs. margarine).  On the first batch, I did forget to flatten slightly and my cookies did not get that nice, cracky look to them.  All of the other batches did so flattening slightly must be the key.  And with the changes that I made, they were nice and puffy, no flat cookies here.  Thanks!!

text:
These were really tasty, but I wouldn't say that they were the best cookies I have ever had. I completely agree with those who found the dough too sticky- it was impossible to make walnut sized balls. I managed with two teaspoons, and just transfered the small splots of dough to the baking paper. Then, I dipped a wooden spoon in orange juice, and coated it in sugar. Lastly, I used the back of the spoon to shape the dough. They were lovely and soft though, and the ginger is spot on. I'm keeping the recipe for next time!

These cookies are delicious.  Worth every star!  I used orange juice instead of water and butter instead of margerine.  I used a medium cookie scoop and just dropped the cookies onto waxed paper.  I put a little shortening on the palms of my hands to make rolling into a ball easier.  I used turbinado sugar to roll the cookies in.  Two TBL of sugar was not enough for rolling.  I used around 1/3 cup.  The turbinado sugar really makes the coookies look nice.

text:
Yummy! I made this with a pumpkin cream cheese dip and it's the perfect autumn combo! Make two batches of cookies for this much dip:  2 8-oz. pkgs. cream cheese (softened), 1 30-oz. can pumpkin, 4 cups powdered sugar, 2 tsp. cinnamon. Mix pumpkin slowly into softened cream cheese and add sugar and cinnamon until all ingredients are smooth and blended. Keep dip refrigerated.

text:
So amazingly good! Changes: I added a couple extra tablespoons of flour, substituted 1/2 cup white sugar with dark brown sugar, added 1/4 tsp nutmeg plus another 1/4 tsp of cinnamon.  I made smaller dough balls than the recipe says (slightly less than tablespoon-sized) and got about 50 cookies. I also froze the dough for about 20 minutes, and rolled the clumps in confectioner's sugar before baking. A definite keeper! Note: be sure to use margarine -- I tried it again with butter and the cookies were not as big and soft.

text:
I used fresh grated ginger instead of the dry stuff and added in a little extra juice. I think that's probably why my dough turned out as runny as cake batter. But two hours in the fridge and it came out fine. I did have a problem with the dough sticking to my hands, but I just dropped spoonfuls of dough into the sugar and then shaped them into balls instead of the other way around. I also kicked up the cloves and ginger, and added a little nutmeg too. Like other reviewers, I found it easier to drop the cookies into a bowl of sugar instead of two Tbs. These came out big and chewy, just like they were supposed to, and made my whole house smell like Thanksgiving!

text:
A big hit at work just as they are or with a little icing.  I've been asked for the recipe more than once.  Suggestion:  while still warm spread a small dollop of buttercream frosting (butter, milk, conf. sugar, vanilla) on top to form a glaze.  I did use butter rather than margarine - worked great.

Update:  I have now made these dozens and dozens of times and they are always delicious.  I make the dough as listed except I use butter.  I have found that they work as a drop cookie if you are in a hurry and don't want to get your hands dirty, but the trade off is that they do not come out as perfect round circles.  Instead of rolling the balls in sugar first, you can sprinkle sugar on them as they come out of the oven or leave it off altogether. These are foolproof.

text:
Very good recipe.   These came out perfectly without any tweaking to the ingredients, but next time (based on other reviews) I will try using orange juice? & 1/2 brown sugar, 1/2 white sugar.     I did tweak the baking instructions, tho, by using my mom’s method:  Did not flatten the balls, then baked 6 min on a lower rack, then turned tray & moved it to higher rack for another 6 minutes.  The trick is to always have 2 trays in, starting on the lower rack (so with the first tray on the bottom, put an empty tray up top, always rotating up & out.  When the final tray of cookies moves to the top rack, put an empty tray on the bottom).

text:
These were great for my first time cooking with molasses! I changed the 1 cup sugar into 3/4 cup sugar + 1 1/2 tsp stevia to cut down on sugar content, though rolling the dough balls in sugar probably made up for that. I wanted cookies that were a little spicier, so I added 1 tbsp finely chopped ginger and 1/4 tsp ground nutmeg. The flavor was definitely enhanced, but I think the best way to get a nice, bold spiciness is to chop up crystallized ginger. I also added another 1 1/2 tablespoons water because the batter just took forever to incorporate. Because of this, I believe that the batter got a little overmixed, which made the cookies drier when baked for a little over 10 minutes. To flatten the dough balls, I lightly scored them with a fork as one would with peanut butter cookies. They didn't spread out very much, which I also attribute to overmixing. I found the best time to be 9 minutes with 15 cookies on a silicone mat.

text:
So, I did these the lazy way. I mixed the dry and wet ingredients separately, but I just whisked them together instead of sifting. I also poured them together in one go, then mixed them by hand instead of getting out the mixer. I used gluten-free flour (Cup For Cup) due to allergies, and butter because I didn't have margarine. I didn't flatten them out because, again, lazy way. Too tired after shopping. Despite the shortcuts and minor ingredient swaps, they taste great. I can't eat this many on my own, so I froze the extras, and they're still great after being thawed. I'm not sure I'd call them "big", but maybe I was supposed to make them bigger. 
They turned out as they were supposed to, they taste great, and they're easy to make. Good recipe.

This is a very good soft ginger cookie.  I was pretty faithful to the recipe.  I didn't have any fresh ginger on hand, so I used 2 thawed cubes of Dorot grated ginger.  This was supposedly two teaspoons, but it wasn't gingery enough for me when I tasted it, so I added a half teaspoon dried ginger as well.  The directions say to bake for 10 minutes, but that just wasn't done enough. I suggest at least 12 minutes, or until they are well cracked.  I'd like them to be a bit more spicy and may fool with that next time.  My only disappointment is that it only makes 24 cookies!  Great recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These cookies are scrumptious.  I read some of the negative reviews and have a few suggestions.  
1. You must refrigerate the dough before forming cookies.  The dough is very sticky.  I  recommend at least one hour in the fridge.  Not sure why the recipe does not say that. 2.  Butter is better in this recipe than margarine, both for taste and consistency.  Butter should be soft but not warm and melting.  3.  If your recipe is "soupy" you need to check your measurements.  The dough is soft and sticky, but not soupy.  4.  If you are not sure whether you like the taste of molasses or cloves, don't make these.  These are strong flavors and IMHO are two ingredients that make the cookies delicious.  5.  I baked the cookies for 12 minutes, and my oven is spot on with temperature.  6.  Let the cookies sit on the cookie sheet for a few minutes before trying to remove them.  Otherwise, they fall apart.  7.  If you are making these cookies for a holiday gift or a cookie display, you may be disappointed in their appearance unless you find a way to decorate them.  They are somewhat flat and a bit plain.  That said, appearances are deceiving when it comes to these cookies.

text:
Ok, so first trial run, made recipe exactly , loved flavor, disappointed when cookies were flat. Also read alot of the reviews...So now on my 5th batch.! My family and friends "Love" them. Ive been told to always have this cookie dough  in refrig. Lol. I must say I agree, so good with morning coffee, snack, after dinner with ice cream. So these are my changes, first added kinda heaping extra 1/4 cup of wheat flour, sifted all & added nutmeg, fresh cracked black pepper to taste also in dry ingreds. Used unsalted real butter and really whipped  and continued whipping with sugar, till very fluffy, then egg, used orange juice instead of water or lemon juice. Lil of the zest also & added flour mixture in 1/2 cup batches mixing well each time. No need to chill, they roll very nice,  I roll in cinnamon/ sugar and bake usually around 10 mins. They come out  soft and chewy, litely crisp around edges and puffy and yummy. Delish and very addictive.!!

text:
I followed this recipe exactly and ended up with very biscuity/cakey cookies. Very round, rather dry, and a bit bland, but not too bad.

Second time I went down to 2 cups of flour and added an extra egg yolk (one full egg + one egg yolk). I also went up to 3 tsp ginger, 2 tsp cinnamon, and 1 full teaspoon cloves. I also added a tbsp of orange juice, as recommended by one other reviewer. (apparently it brings out the other flavors?) I liked the second version significantly better, and they came out more chewy and less crumbly. 

Good starting point for a recipe, though I'm very confused how anyone got those pictures from 2 1/4 cups of flour. (Disclaimer: although I spooned in the flour the first time, I don't own a baking scale, so maybe my measuring was off.)

text:
These cookies are delicious, but the recipe needs a little tweaking to get the consistency right. As written, the cookies will spread out a lot while baking and don’t hold together well. I made these changes and they came out perfect:
- Use slightly softened butter instead of margarine
- Replace water with orange juice, as other reviews recommend
- Add about 1/4 cup additional flour
- Freeze dough for about 30 minutes before baking
- Double the baking soda 
- Don't flatten when placed on baking sheet
- Double the ground ginger

As others have noted, the batter/dough tastes amazing, but these cookies are nearly impossible to make. I've made them twice now. The first attempt, I ended up using nearly double the flour to try and get the dough to a consistency that would form into balls. they ended up tasting like gingerbread(ish) scones. The 2nd attempt, I followed the recipe exactly, then stuck the dough in the fridge for just under 24 hours. Managed to get 12 spoonfuls of dough rolled in sugar and onto cookie sheets, but they still wouldn't roll into balls. Will not be making again.

text:
this cookies are great! but I have some recomendatiins. 1. add less sugar (1 cup sugar + 1/4cup molasses and sugar to roll the dough - it is too much, at least for me (commonly I add 1 cup of sugar for 3 cups of flour, so for this recipe 3/4 cup. but since we have molasses here, I would add 1/4cup sugar, or no sugar at all). 2. let the mixture sit in the fridge for about 30-40min and stir it occasionally to let the dough thicken everywhere. 3. flatten the cookie with a glass very well to get this form from a video. 4. when I rolled my cookies the dough was pretty hard (because it stayed in the fridge) and it is very easy to roll it. first I made all cookie balls, then rolled them in sugar. when you make one ball, then roll it in sugar and start to make another ball - you add sugar, that sticked to your fingers, to the dough and it is a lot of sugar. after you rolled all cookies - flatten them with a glass.

I've made this cookie recipe for years and I love it. I always come back to it every Christmas. I've had someone tell me she doesn't like gingerbread cookies, but she likes these. I use butter instead of margarine (not a fan of margarine). One thing I always experiment with is the time. For me, they always come out too soft and flat when I cook them for only 10 minutes. (They're still a bit raw in the middle and they can't hold their form so when they come out of the oven they flatten out and lose all their puff, Maybe it's my oven???) I forget every year and always end up adding more time (12-15 total minutes) for the second batch. They come out perfect.

text:
Been making this recipe for many years now but never bothered to review. My favorite cookie.  Our changes:

We put the walnut size balls of dough into the freezer for ~10 minutes before baking. When we put them on the cookie sheet after rolling in sugar we flatten them to between 1/4" and 1/2".

The order of mixing is super important.

In most ovens a 1 Tbsp scoop (~walnut sized) takes about 10 minutes, but it usually takes until the second batch to get the timing right. Undercooking is better than overcooking by far.

Oh, and we have never used margarine, always unsalted butter with this recipe. We tried the grand marnier thing, tried orange juice instead of the water, too, and never noticed a difference. We tried the brown sugar instead of  or in combo with the molasses and prefer the original recipe.

If you do it right you get a great, thick, soft, chewy cookie with a big rush of flavor and perfect mouthfeel.

These were simple and DELICIOUS. I used orange juice instead of water as suggested by others.  I also took the suggestion of dropping the dough in the sugar and then working them into balls.  It wasn’t hard to work with that way.  I didn’t flatten them out too much, rather made a bit of a thumb print in them.  They’re crispy on the outside and a little soft inside.   I also added a dash of nutmeg to the batter to intensify the flavours.  VERY GOOD. My husband says they’re like his mom’s (big shoes to fill)

text:
This recipe is now in my family cookbook album.  I made one batch and my margarine was frozen so I made them with unsalted butter.  They turned out AMAZING!!! Before they were cooled and while I still had all the ingredients out, I made a second batch (doubled) with margarine.  I had no issues with rolling them out or the dough being sticky.  My six littles helped me roll them into balls and in the sugar and put them on the pans.  They baked wonderfully in about 9 minutes and flattened the perfect amount.  This will definitely be one of my go-to recipes when I want a ginger cookie fix without the hassle of rolling and cutting out.  My whole family loved them and my husband took a couple dozen to work with him this morning.  I have a feeling I'll be making more in a few days as we won't make it to Christmas with these batches.

text:
Always buy fresh spices for this recipe and a good quality to. It makes a difference. I bought McCormick (red top) and Badia brand (found in the international Hispanic food section) of each spice needed. McCormick was far superior in smell and taste.But for a milder less pungent Badia is good. So to give any recipe a fair review start with fresh good quality spices/herbs etc not what’s been in the cupboard from a year ago. I also added finely chopped candied ginger(Trader Joe’s) I have a small mini food processor for cutting up ginger. I used six 3x1inch pieces but adjust to your taste

text:
Love these. I made these today and they came out great. I don't like cinnamon much, so I used only 1/8 tsp of cinnamon and added 1/8 tsp nutmeg. I also used a touch less cloves because I thought it was too much. I mix everything by hand; I don't have an electric mixer. They took 13 minutes to cook in my oven but cookies tend to take longer in my oven from my experience. They taste wonderful. I am so happy to have a reliable recipe for soft ginger molasses cookies. Just so you know, if you watch the video, you can see how these cookies actually look after baking. They do not look as crackled as the photo. I got more than the 24 the video says you get, but they weren't quite as large as shown either. Highly recommended.

text:
I've made these twice now and we love them!  The first time I made them, I wasn't sure they were fully baked because of the way they looked and so I overbaked some.  The baking time is about right.  I also have realized that baking on the top vs bottom oven rack makes a big difference.  In order to get them to look like the picture, I have to bake on top rack.  If I bake on bottom rack, the bottom burns before the top rises and "cracks" like the picture shows.  I rolled mine in Turbinado sugar (plenty of it) before baking and that was preferred to the regular sugar in the recipe.

text:
Even altered to be VEGAN these cookies are awesome!  Just subbed butter flavored Crisco for the margarine and a flax egg (1 T ground flaxseed and 3 T water mixed and set aside for a few minutes) for the egg, and added additional water, about two more tablespoons, until the consistency of the dough seemed right. Everything else was kept the same.  Super easy and super yummy!

text:
So good! We've been using a store-bought mix for our gingerbread cookies for years, but not after finding this recipe! I started making it and realized that I didn't have any ginger. Uhhh, that was kind of silly on my part (they're GINGERbread cookies, after all), but I ended up simply adding 1 teaspoon of cinnamon instead of 3/4. They were great! I did take some other reviewers' advice and let the dough rest in the fridge for about 30 minutes before baking. This really did make the dough a lot less sticky and a lot easier to work with. My cookies took about 10 minutes to bake. Of course, they're so flavorful on their own, but we're frosting addicts, so I put some vanilla frosting I found in my pantry on them. YUM! Thanks so much for the recipe and for all the tips!

I'm sorry, I know I should follow the recipe to the T, I completely understand, but I've never added water to a cookie recipe, and I got scared. I've also heard the brown sugar makes chocolate chip cookies the "soft inside, crunchy outside" type, and so those are the ONLY two changes I made.

Omitted the water, and did 3/4 cup white sugar, 1/4 cup brown sugar.

Baked them for the mentioned 8-10 minutes. I didn't know how to know if they were done, so Googled, and it said that when the edges of the cookie are firm, they're done!

Pulled them out, and they look, taste, smell, PHENOMENAL! Everything is amazing. Loved them!

Thank you for this recipe, can't wait for my husband to come home and try them =)

text:
This recipe made amazingly soft ginger cookies.  I upped the flour to 2 1/2 cups after reading other reviews, and although the dough was still sticky, it was easy to work with.  The only other changes I made were to use butter instead of margarine and granulated brown sugar instead of white sugar in order to avoid processed ingredients.

My cookies did crack like in the photos, but I learned that it was a problem with the temperature of the dough before going in the oven and the leavening.  Our house does not have air-conditioning, so the kitchen was warm, making my dough warm thus flattening too soon in the oven.  Next time I make them during the summer months, I will refrigerate the dough before putting them in the oven, and I may try adding a little baking powder to increase the leavening so the top sets while the middle is still trying to rise.

These cookies have been a hit at every party I've brought them to. Three things I do differently: (1) I use 1/3 cup molasses - it makes it easier for my ancient hand-mixer to deal with. (2) I always add a 1/2 teaspoon of ground cardamom. I love cardamom so hard. (3) When I'm making them for my mum, I replace the cloves with an equal amount of allspice. (Apparently, cloves were used as an anesthetic when she had dry socket as a child?)

(When I've run out of molasses, a half-and-half mixture of pancake syrup and honey worked in a pinch.)

text:
I made these this past weekend, and I followed recipe directions. I read other reviews concerning the stickiness of the dough. I had no problem with it. Yes, the dough was sticky, but only a wee bit stuck to my fingers, and certainly wasn't so sticky that it was a problem. My family's peanut butter cookie recipe is stickier than this one. 

The only recommendation I have is regarding the instructions to flatten the balls of dough. I found that it is better to either flatten balls only slightly or flatten quite thin. (I used the bottom of my 1 cup stainless measuring cup. I also used granulated sugar on the bottom of measuring cup to minimize the chance that they would stick to it.

Easy recipe, and I'll definitely add this into my baking routine. (Bonus was how awesome they smelled when baking.)

text:
Love these. I did make a couple small changes. I had a bit of brown sugar left from something else that I subbed in for part of the white sugar. I had 1 large and 2 smaller eggs (I doubled the recipe on faith) so for a double recipe I used the 3 eggs. I also left out the water based on previous comments. I don't think any of these changes alter the overall recipe significantly.
They came out perfectly--crispy on the outside, moist and chewy on the inside.  Two days later most of the double batch is gone and I'm going to have to make more.
I do recommend using a scoop to avoid the sticky dough/ball problem.

text:
These are simple and delicious. I followed the recipe for the most part but I took others advice and chilled the dough in the refrigerator for an hour before I rolled them into balls. The directions are slightly flawed for getting the actual shape and size of the cookies down right. I rolled them into a walnut sized ball like the directions stated, rolled the ball in some sugar, then I took a Pyrex measuring cup and flattened the cookies to make them big. Please make sure to do this only after you've rolled the dough balls in sugar...this will help with sticking to the bottom of the glass....press down lightly it did stay stuck to the bottom every now & then so do this carefully. All in all these are yummy and it's the name of them holds true "big soft ginger cookies" this is a new holiday favorite of mine. Please try!! So very easy and delicious.

text:
Disclaimer - I typically don't bake-my wife does.  But she's a strict - stick to the ingredients - baker.  I, however, wanted to try to make something with a normal recipe but use substitutes to make it healthier and work around our lactose intolerance.

Replaced the butter with our non-dairy butter, replaced the sugar with honey (read somewhere to use 1/2-3/4 cup for every 1 cup of sugar and cook 25 degrees cooler), gluten free flour, and orange juice instead of water.  

2 things I could've done better - read more reviews.  I think I would've had much better results if I would've let it sit for a little while before putting it on the cookie sheet.  It was really gooey.  Also, I thought I was using a tsp when I was really using a 1/2 tsp, so I had to go back and add more of everything.  I than realized I forgot 1 tsp of ground ginger after the first batch was in the oven, so I added 1/2 tsp to what was still in the bowl-they seemed to stick together better.  

I was also hoping for a little more of a solid cookie on the exterior.  But I might be thinking of another cookie.  Maybe it was molasses cookies...  But my wife seems to like them, so that's good.

Good enough, but not like Peets ginger cookies - my goal for best cookies ever.  Needs more ginger, suggest 1 Tablespoon, increase cinnamon to 1 tsp and use 1 Tb hot water not cold.  Change white to brown sugar (1 cup).  Cook at least 9 minutes and be sure you use lowest shelf in oven or oven heats evenly with more than one tray.  If you add 1/2 cup chunky chopped crystalized ginger pieces, you've got a winner!

text:
I followed the recipe for the most part. I used an equal amount of dark corn syrup instead of molasses and I rolled the dough in a sugar-cinnamon mix instead. The syrup was only because the closest place that sells molasses is a good bit away. I'm not sure if it impacted the flavor at all. The cinnamon in the sugar really enhanced the flavor, but it would be better to just sprinkle it on top instead of rolling. 

The cookies came out as flat as a cookie can be, as some other reviews have said. If I make them again, I would definitely try brown sugar instead of syrup. Overall, the cookies tasted great. They were very sweet and had an excellent gingery taste that did not overpower while still having the hints of cloves and such. 

I made half of them at the lower baking time range and at the higher. The lower time range has stayed soft and chewy even now, three days later. The higher time range had crispy edges with a soft center. 

The only problem is that they look nothing like the picture at the top of the page. My cookies look like flat discs and are beige like a peanut butter cookie. They have no cleavage except for the one I dropped when taking it off the pan.

I have used this recipe twice now within the last month. The first time was the week of Christmas. I followed the recipe word for word. Except my dough balls were a little larger than a teaspoon and I didn't flatten them much at all. They turned out delicious! 

I gave some to all of our neighbors (they ranted and raved at how soft and delicious they were). I took most of them to my aunt-in-law's house to add to the dessert table Christmas Day. My husband and I had to leave right after dinner to drive over the pass to spend Christmas with my mother (where we took the cookies to as well). My mother and her husband loved them! Moreover, come Monday evening when my husband came home, he couldn't wait to tell me that the cookies were a HUGE hit at his aunt's house. I had made too many, so she brought them to work (they work together). The cookies were devoured within the first few hours of the day! 

I know, this is long. But, I have to share the success I had with this recipe. Anywho, I made these cookies again last week, this time only 48 cookies. I decided to alter the recipe by being generous with the measurements for ginger, cinnamon, and cloves. I also added 5 extra tablespoons of molasses. OH MY GOSH! HOLY CANOLLI! They were to die for! My husband took them to work again, this time he came home to tell me that his aunt claimed that they tasted almost like Nana's. That is the biggest compliment I could ever receive or give. Thank you very much for sharing this recipe!

text:
These cookies are really delicious, with a wonderful texture, an almost crisp, crackly outside and soft, chewy center.  The dough is very sticky, so I highly recommend refrigerating the dough before using it. I baked some right away and put the rest of the dough in the fridge and the cold dough was much easier to work with and I feel like the spice flavors came out more from having time to incorporate into the dough. 

Every one who tried them loved them, even the people who say they don't like sweets or ginger. I think this is partly because the ginger flavor is not very strong in this cookie. I made it exactly as written and it tasted more like a very flavorful and rich snicker doodle. This is a 5 star cookie on its own merit. However, I did deduct one star for the fact that it's called a ginger cookie but doesn't really taste very ginger-y as I was hoping. This will definitely be in my holiday cookie rotation, but my search for the perfect ginger cookie goes on.

text:
BEST ginger cookies ever! 

A few changes: 
butter instead of margarine.  I did not flatten the cookies because I found they came out nicer when they weren't flattened.  I baked with aluminum foil lined cookie sheets
and set out 8 balls of dough per sheet (only have 2 cookie sheets) and this had them not 'run into' each other and made for nicer looking cookies. The yield for each batch was greater that 24 cookies, even though I shaped them into walnut sized balls. If cloves are too strong for your taste, try substituting with nutmeg. Side note:  I misread the molasses to be 1 1/4 cup on one batch, however, we couldn't really tell the difference and it didn't affect the overall flavour and softness that much.

text:
These cookies are one of my favorite recipes to make during the holiday season, and are pretty much perfect as written. I like to increase the amount of spices used in the batter, because I prefer strong flavors. I personally didn't notice much of a difference between using orange juice or water, so don't worry if you can't make the substitution suggested by another reviewer. I've never had trouble manipulating the dough, and I like to use a measuring cup to roll the dough balls around and coat them in sugar. These cookies stay soft and delicious for quite a long time, and are also flat and sturdy, which makes them excellent cookies to send through the mail.  I love to microwave them for a few seconds before eating them; they taste like they've just come out of the oven again!

text:
These were pretty good; however, they lacked a little in flavor.  Next time, I'll increase the molasses to 1/2 cup and use the dark/full flavor molasses and increase the flour by 1/4 (to compensate for the added moisture).  I'll also add 1/2 teaspoon of vanilla.  My first batch, I flattened a lot per other reviews and my second batch I only flattened slightly...this made the cookies raw in the middle.  My third batch, I flattened slightly but baked 12 minutes and they seem to be the best (otherwise they are so soft they fall apart).  Even if you flatten them a lot, they still are very soft.  I also chilled the dough (outside in MN) for some time before forming the balls.  This made the dough very easy to work with.  I also used butter instead of margarine.

text:
Nice spice taste that sort of reminds you of the holidays. Delicious and very easy to make. I followed many of the reviewers' recommendations of replacing the water with orange juice. I also refrigerated the dough for about 30 min, and I feel that made it easier to work with. Rolled the ~3/4" balls in sugar and pressed down a bit with the bottom of a glass. They do spread so don't place too close together. Very soft and seem like they will stay that way if stored properly. A definite keeper! UPDATE 1/27/16: Second time making these, and they came out even better. Refrigerated dough for 1 hr 15 min (would chill even longer) which helped to achieve the desired cracks in the cookies. I made them smaller and did not press down top; this worked fine, they nicely spread out. I used 1/2 cup ICBINB and 1/4 c Crisco. I replaced the water with spiced rum. Baked exactly 8 min. Soft, chewy, delicious.
