text:
Decent recipe - I chilled the mixture for 30 mins before making as it was a bit too soft - but otherwise turned out good. A bit bland, but very eatable

2nd time I 'kicked it up a notch' I upped the ingredients to the following:

2.5 tsp ginger
1 tsp cinnamon
1/3cup molasses

and then I add 1 tsp vanilla to the 2 Tbsp of water. I then dusted them with confectioners sugar.

WHAT A DIFFERENCE!!

The cookies now have 'pop' and 'zing' the flavor is now awesome instead of just okay.

I give this four stars based on these changes I made based on some of the reviews and the fact that I found this recipe in my Better Homes and Gardens recipe book from 1986. It has these changes: 2tsp. baking soda, 1tsp. ginger, 1tsp. cinnamon, NO salt, 3/4 brown sugar and don't add water. I sugared and flattened some cookies for a thin, soft cookie with crunchy edges and the ones I left as a sugared ball have a nice crinkle on top.

text:
I just made these cookies and can't stop eating them!  These are seriously delicious cookies, and like other cooks, I found the dough a little too soft to form balls, so I added an additional 1/4 cup of flour and they turned out soft and amazing. Next time I am going to add orange juice in place of water and 1/4 tsp. cardamom and make a double batch to see how well they freeze. I highly recommend this recipe exactly as it is if you have time to chill the dough before rolling them into balls - otherwise, just add a little extra flour and you are good to go! I made them for my husband's lunchbox treat, but at this point, I'm not sure they will make it that far! Thank you for this yummy contribution!

country:
None
text:
I was very happy at how chewy these stayed. I picked this recipe because I had all the ingredients in my cabinet except the cloves, so I replaced those with some pumpkin pie spice which I knew had cloves in it. The flavor was still great. I rolled the first batch in sugar and found that to be overkill for me, so the second batch went in with just sugar on the top half of the cookie, still a little much so the last cookies in the oven got no extra sugar, and I kept those for myself and let the kids eat the sugar coated ones. I also didn't refrigerate the dough at all, it would have probably helped to keep the dough from being sooo sticky, but I didn't think it was too big of an issue. My cookies rose a little when baking but not much, so I think this wouldn't be the best dough for rolling out and cutting into shapes. Other ginger cookie recipes I have used seem to be made more for that type of cookie, the kind that snaps and is crunchier. I loved these because they were chewy and stayed that way for the next couple days till they were all gone.

AMAZING.

My adjustments: Substitute butter-flavored Crisco for margarine. (Easy to work with, rich flavor, creamy texture.)

You guys don't understand- these cookies are dangerous. They will disappear in a day and you will be like, What? Where did they go? I don't remember eating all of those! But you DID. You did, and that's why you can't fit into your jeans any more.

I've made this recipe dozens of times. Every time it's a little bit different, due to weather/humidity/my own imperfections, but that's okay. Sometimes I squish the cookies flatter, sometimes thicker, sometimes they're crispier and sometimes they're chewier. But every time they have been DELICIOUS. You can't go wrong, so just jump right in there!

text:
Awesome cookies!  Today was my first day making them.  I read through many reviews first and took note of tips.  Instead of water I used orange juice.  I Sprayed the measuring cup with oil so the molasses would easily pour.  
And I cooled the dough in the freezer for a half hour.  It was very easy to work with. 
I kept all of the ingredients and measurements the same other than the water.  And I did exactly what the directions said.  And I sifted the flour etc.  
I found that 8 -10 minutes wasn't enough baking time.  Maybe it's my oven.  12 minutes is just right for my oven.   They turned out very yummy. They have a Slight crisp on the outside and are chewy on the inside.  And the flavor is just right.  
I made 30 cookies out of this recipe. I will definitely make them again.

These taste just like ginger snaps but are softer. Yummy! I did change one thing. I used butter instead of margarine. Using butter will eliminate the "sticky" feel prior to cooking and makes them easier to handle. If you want the crinkle top form into balls and just drop on cookie sheet after coating in sugar. They flatten out on their own and when they dry there is a very pretty authentic crinkle top.

text:
This recipe worked out for me.....soft but chewy.  Coincidentally, this recipe was almost exactly the one printed on the back of "Mother's Molasses" bottle.  The amounts of the spices were different, (which is all a matter of personal taste anyway) as was the baking soda, which called for 2 teaspoons (I used 1 1/2) Also, I used brown sugar instead of white, which was what was called for on molasses bottle. I never use margarine, so I used butter instead. I refrigerated the dough for 1 hour and had no problem with stickiness shaping the balls (I also kept the dough refrigerated in between making batches) I did not have to flatten the balls, they baked perfectly. I also found that they baked best at around 8-9 minutes. The flavor was good, those of you that like more spice just have to  experiment with this, but honestly, I don't know why people had all these different  problems.

text:
I love gingersnaps.  I've never had a soft ginger cookie before.  We made these with our little ones (3 1/2 years old).  We only made three modifications to the recipe: 1) substituted butter for margarine, that's what we had in the house, 2) instead of 2 1/2 cups of AP flour, we used 1 1/2 cups of AP and 3/4 cups of whole wheat flour - I wanted to see if it would create a dense cookie, it didn't and 3) to a third of the batch we added in white chocolate chips.  
We baked one batch for 9 minutes- soft in the middle, with a ever-so-slight crunch on the outside.
We baked the second batch for 11 minutes- not quite gingersnap, but definitely more on the hard side.  
Verdict- delicious!  I wasn't sure if my little kidabunks would like them - ginger being a strong scent and flavor, however  my cookie-loving daughter devoured four of them.  
The next time we bake these, we are not going to roll them in sugar; it made them a bit too sweet- it doesn't need it.
Thank you Amy for a delicious new cookie my family can enjoy making and eating together each Christmas

I love these cookies BUT ... 

I made these last year (added extra ginger). The cookies looked just like the picture and tasted awesome. This year I substituted the orange juice (this is one of the preferred edits) with orange liqueur, and although the cookies taste devine, they are really flat (and I am not even pressing them down).  Not sure why.  However, my cookies do look like those in the video for this recipe.  

At any rate, this recipe produces exceptionally tasty cookies.  You need to use quality (fresh) spices.  If the spices are stale, your cookies will be bland.  I suspect this is one of the issues with people who rate this recipe poorly.

I'm giving this 5 stars, based on my 2012 results. I assume I did something wrong in 2013.  I made 4X the recipe for a cookie exchange.  My cookies will be the ugly ducklings (they were last year too), but they will still be the yummiest.

text:
This recipe was really good.  I rarely eat gingerbread but for some reason I was craving it.  I thought it was going to be way harder than it was.  As long as you're not expecting to be able to roll this dough out and make cookie cuter gingerbread men, then this is a great recipe.   The few things I did different:  I, like many other reviewers, added 1 TBSP orange juice instead of water.  The recipe also says to roll the dough into balls, roll in sugar, an put on the cookie sheet.  After reading some of the reviews and getting to that point myself, I concluded that that was not going to be possible without refrigerating the dough (which I really did not want to do as I hate waiting for it to chill).  Instead, I sprayed two spoons with cooking oil lightly, coated in sugar, and then rolled the dough, drop cookie style.  I then repeated this proceedure with a fork to allow me to flatted the cookies as if I were making peanut butter cookies.  You can't see the marks like you would in a peanutbutter cookie and they tasted delicious, though they were a little flat (but this did not bother me).

text:
These were delicious. I had to make another batch over the holidays because they disappeared so fast. I also used the gingerbread frosting from this site (you need to double that recipe to cover 1 batch of these cookies).

I used room temperature butter instead of margarine because I like it better. I also doubled the spices just because we love the kick-but it tends to be too much for kids. I didn't have to flatten a whole lot like another review stated because butter tends to spread out. Someone complained that they were too flat. Well ginger and molasses cookies are supposed to be flat. These aren't drop cookies! Make sure you don't put them too close together and you will have mighty fine cookies.

This is just what I was looking for! I am so happy I found this delicious recipe! Look no further! They have a great flavor and come out soft and chewy! The only thing I did different is I used butter instead of margarine. The ginger does give it quite a kick! I asked my husband if I should use a tad less when I make them again and he said "No!" because "I love, love, love them"! I did not have any problems forming them into balls or them falling flat and hard. Watch the video. Refrigerate the dough for 30-45 minutes. Flour your hands each ball you make. Roll it the size of a walnut and press it slightly with the bottom of the cup. In ten minutes later mine came out perfect. I have a new addiction!

text:
Was feeling the holiday spirit, and this caught my eye.  All in all, very good, but very sweet.  My first thought is not to roll them in sugar at all.  As it was, I only dipped the top in the sugar, and it was still sweeeeeet.  I didn't get puffy cookies, but that's probably because I over-creamed the butter/sugar.  I did use 1/2 butter and 1/2 butter flavored Crisco which could have had a little to do with that.  Frankly, I think they didn't need to be flattened.  First tray I cooked closer to 8 minutes, and the second tray I cooked closer to 10.  I liked the 10 minute ones.  Better crispy outer layer, but still soft in the middle.  I will give it another go, but I will be more careful creaming, and I will leave them as balls like I do my sugar cookies.  Oh, unless you are one of "those" people who can manage to eat just one cookie and be done, double the recipe.  2 dozen cookies is just a tease.

Excellent cookie. Read reviews before baking so I chilled dough in frig 30 mins before baking. That was a good suggestion as dough is very sticky. I baked one batch without flattening and another flattening slightly. The batch that I did not flatten turned out looking like the picture and were the size of Ginger Snaps. The other batch did not look like the picture and were too thin. I cooked the remaining dough without flattening. Also (don't know if this makes a difference), I didn't have 3/4 cup softened margarine, so used 1/2 cup butter-flavored Crisco and 1/4 cup softened butter. Thanks for posting this wonderful recipe.

I have made these cookies for years now and they are always a hit for gifts at christmas time; simple, tasty and look beautiful wrapped up. I have never had trouble with the stickiness other talk about - they are a snap to make. Not that they will last long, but they actually do stay chewy. Baked a bit longer they also make a great snap.  I recently subbed in fancy molasses for regular, just cause it's what I had on hand - and the hubby actually noticed and said he loved them even more! Yum Yum.

Exceptional! These stayed soft for the short time they were in the house - they had a habit of being devoured quickly.  The dough was a bit sticky, as others have noted, but some spray helped and the results were well worth it.  I did try to use this recipe in a gingerbread house shaped cookie pan I bought, but the results weren't great.  The cookies lost their soft, chewiness.  I suspect that will be a common problem regardless of the recipe I use in that pan, possibly due to the thickness.  My son didn't seem to care though and loved the shapes.  I'll stick to the round cookies.  Before I forget, they spread well so I found that I didn't need to flatten them - even with frozen dough.

text:
These cookies are wonderful!  I made them for a potluck new year's day party and they went very quickly.  I've also sealed them in a vacuum sealed bag and shipped them to Afghanistan for a friend in the military.  He said that they kept very well and were still chewy when he got them.  The only alterations I make are that I don't skimp on the spices.  I use a whole teaspoon for both the cinnamon and the ground cloves.  Like other reviewers I also substituted orange juice for the water, although either are suitable.  Also, before I assemble and bake them I like to refrigerate the dough for a little while.  This makes it much easier to handle and they turn out better in the baking process.  Great recipe :)  I definitely recommend it!

This is the first rating I have written, though I have used this site for a while.  These cookies are amazing.  I have made them 3-4 times now, and they get better every time.  The dough is sticky, so I put it in the freezer for 20-30 minutes, and coat my hands with and dip a fork in flour to flatten them.  I skip rolling them in sugar.  I go heavy on the spices, and have used orange juice once and water the other times.  That doesn't seem to make much of a difference.  These are the best!!!!

text:
Oh my GOD, these are so good and so simple to make. I didn't have to beat in the egg, my butter/sugar mixture was soft enough that it made it easier to mix in. Tip: Heat butter at 30% power for a minute to a minute and a half, after cutting it into little pieces. It will make mixing easier, especailly if you have a broken beater like I do. Also, there is no need for the extra sugar in the end, they are fine by themselves. Well, they do make them prettier...

text:
This recipe is deelish! The dough should definitely be chilled prior to shaping the cookies. I pop it into the freezer for 20 mins before the first batch and then in between batches. I like to do the cookie balls smaller because they are rather rich but I don't flatten them. I find that when they poof up the middle stays softer longer (although they don't last long in my house. I also like to use turbinado sugar (not raw) to coat them.

These are fantastic cookies!!  The whole family loves them...including a 2 and 5 year old.  I did do a few things differently; I used a cup of whole wheat flour and 1 1/4 cup of all purpose, I added some cinnamon to the sugar when I rolled them and I also put the dough in the freezer before I rolled them into balls.  When I pressed them with a fork they baked out really flat so I just used my fingers to flatten them a little bit and they turned out perfectly!  This is a keeper!  Thanks so much.

text:
These really are good.  I followed the recipe exactly as written except for omitting the final step of rolling the dough in sugar.  I don't like things too sweet.  The came out great!  Soft and tender.  The ginger flavor is present without being overpowering (ginger lovers add more - someone's written about how much more they added).  One review mentioned that the clove flavor was overwhelming but I didn't not find this to be true.  I like the flavor of clove so that might be why I am not bothered by it.   I will try the orange juice substitution next time.  I also want to try adding some pumpkin flavor; it seems like the pumpkin, ginger and clove are a match made in heaven.  Overall, great cookies!

text:
After reading all the great reviews, I just *had* to try these cookies. Now, I have made A LOT of cookies over the years – especially for gifts at Christmas time – and unfortunately, I strongly disagree that this cookie is one of the best I've tasted. Honestly, I wouldn't even put it in my top 20 cookie recipes.   They came out exactly like they were supposed to; I had no issues like others stated with baking or the dough being too sticky. My issue was with the amount of cloves in the recipe. I felt it was overwhelming, even a day or two later after the flavors had a chance to develop. I'm not even sure why they are called "Ginger" cookies; they should be called "Clove" cookies…that’s how strong the taste of cloves is in this cookie! I still tasted the cloves long after I finished eating the cookie and found myself looking for something else to eat just to cleanse my palette.   I think if the amount of cloves in the recipe was decreased by at least half (maybe more, depending on taste) then I would give these cookies an additional star. The soft texture of the cookie was definitely one of the better attributes and perhaps it would be worth the effort after the minor adjustment to the amount of spices.

These cookies are absolutely delicious. They have enough spicy ginger flavor, like a ginger snap. They have a soft center, and I cook them at the 10-11min. They make a good presentation for plating. Sometimes I give cookies away as gifts and these are wonderfully round in shape. I don't think you need to roll them in sugar. The icing is a nice touch, and you can sprinkle them with raw sugar to add some sparkle and more sweetness if you like. My son who doesn't like molasses, gingerbread cookies really liked these cookies. They have a ginger snap taste.

text:
OK!  So dear Hubby came home from work and proceded to shove cookie after cookie in his mouth!  He stated that 'these were the best cookies I have ever made.'   After reading several reviews, I swapped OJ for the water.  That is the only change I made.  Great cookies!  Easy to make!  Highly recommend!  FOLLOW-UP...I made these cookies and did not have any OJ.  Who would think that ONE tablespoon of OJ would make such a difference!  The best way to describe the lack of OJ is that the spicy flavor of the cookies was not as 'bright'.  SO.....always use OJ while making these cookies. **ANOTHER FOLLOWUP**Since I don't always have OJ in the frig, I use Grand Marnier instead of OJ...works just at well for that little boost of orange flavor!

Amazing cookies.  After mixing the dough it seemed way too runny to make into balls - but I put it in the freezer for 10 minutes and that is all it needed.  They came out great.  The only changes I made was to use 1/2 butter and 1/2 margerine instead of all margerine.  Also I use a small Bulgarian oven, so they took only about 4 minutes each to bake at about 170c.  I took them to a youth leadership group in Macedonia and for many it was the first time they had a molasses cookie - but they loved them - they were gone in minutes.

text:
I made these cookies for the first time this year to give as Christmas gifts.  They were excellent.  Just the right spice. I've since had friends calling me for the recipe. I always use butter in my cookies to make them moist and chewy.  I live at 7100 feet elevation, so I have to make adjustments to all my recipes and these came out right the first time. For anyone else baking at high elevations, for a triple batch I increased flour by 2 Tablespoons, decreased baking soda by 1/4 teaspoon, decreased sugar by 2 Tablespoons and increased water by 5 teaspoons.  Refrigerate the dough before making the cookies and use a small ice cream scoop for perfectly shaped cookies.  Want an easy way to measure sticky ingredients such as molasses and honey? Check out Wonder Cup, which can be purchased at many kitchen stores. Have a Merry Christmas everyone!

I just finished making these cookies. Fantastic recipe.  I used orange juice instead of water. There's no need to roll into balls or get your hands dirty.  Once mixed, put the mixture in the fridge for about 10 minute.  Put some granulated sugar in a shallow bowl. Drop by teaspoonfuls into the sugar and roll. Then place on a cookie sheet and slightly flatten when the bottom of a cup.  9 minutes in the oven and they're perfect.

text:
These are definitely one of the best cookies I've had.  I've made them twice now.  The only thing I did differently was use blackstrap molasses instead of regular, because that was all I had.  Otherwise, I followed the recipe as is.  I found the dough only slightly stickier than other cookie dough recipes where you're rolling them in your hands.  I didn't refrigerate the dough before-hand and it was still fine...you just have to be a little more gentle when you're rolling them.  I've always loved the Archway brand molasses cookies, because they were so soft, and have been trying to find a similar recipe for a couple of years now.  I've found it, although these are way better!  I'm definitely adding this to my favorites, and I will definitely be making lots of these in the next couple of months...it's already a family favorite!

This is exactly the recipe I've been looking for. The texture is just perfect. Soft, yet chewy around the edges. I took some of the other reviewers' suggestions and chilled the dough for a bit and also flattened them before baking. I was also quite generous with the spices and molasses and added some allspice and nutmeg in addition to the other spices. I used brown sugar because that is what I had on hand, and it worked wonderfully, though next time I think I'll try with white just to see how much that changes things. As always, I used butter instead of margarine.  I'll definitely be making this recipe over and over again. Yum!!

These cookies are phenomenal.  My 3 1/2 year old daughter and I made them today.  We also found the dough to be soft and sticky, but I chalked it up to the fact that I used butter flavored crisco instead of margarine.  When using crisco, you have to add water, which I did.  I also added the water required by the recipe.  I thought that is why it was sticky.  I tried the cooking oil on hands trick, but this stuff was just too sticky.  The first batch was too flat.  I added about 1/3 cup more flour then the dough was fine to work with.  The rest of the cookies are perfectly puffy and soft and chewy.  We love them!  Will make again and try the OJ.

text:
This cookie was really tasty and full of flavor! I've never really liked ginger cookies but this recipe really made me change my mind :D I skipped the cloves and added extra cinnamon and a little nutmeg. Then I followed other users' advice on adding orange juice instead of water. I didn't have grounded ginger so I used grated fresh ginger and it worked very well. I also didn't have molasses but I substituted it with 1/4 cup mix of honey and brown sugar. I also put the dough in the freezer so it wouldn't be so sticky and hard to work with. I found the cookie a little difficult to take off the cookie sheet so I baked them on wax paper at 375 for 10 minutes. Despite all the substitutions, the cookie is a delight in every bite!

text:
These were yummy. I definitely tweaked it. I doubled the spices and used butter instead of margerine. I did not have any white sugar on hand so I substituted with brown sugar which I think worked better because it feels like a better fit for ginger cookies. I also forgot to add salt and baking soda and guess what? they still came out soft and poofy! I also did not roll it in sugar before baking. I baked it as is and made a powdered sugar and milk glaze to drizzle on the cookies after they cooled. I just added powdered sugar to 2 tblsp. milk and once it was at the correct consistency I drizzled over cookies. The result: BIG SOFT GINGE COOKIES!!! These are a keeper! Thank You!!!

text:
I'm surprised after reading such raving reviews that I did not enjoy these cookies.  The only substitution I made was using light butter instead of margarine...and I think that's what went wrong.  The dough was so soft that it was impossible to form it into balls.  After baking, they were very thin and hard.  They had a decent taste, albeit slightly bland.  I would add more seasoning next time.

Basically, DO NOT USE LIGHT BUTTER!  I hope to try this recipe again at some point because I'm sure the cookies were supposed to come out better than mine did.

text:
These cookies truly were some of the best ginger cookies I've tasted. I'm not sure where the "BIG" comes in though. Mine were just the average size. I also used the orange juice instead of water. I think it's very important to note that the dough should be refrigerated before forming into balls. This type of cookie always needs this step, and it might have been an oversight. These stayed soft right up to the end (which wasn't too long). Truly a keeper!

I love bakingup mystery sweets for my family to test and this one stood out.  I did however substitute 1/4 cup of brown sugar for molasses...i'm not a huge molasses fan.  I also left them in the oven for a few more minutes so time ran between 10-13 minutes.

The best cookies for the holiday season! I made the following changes: substituted the orange juice for water and butter for the margarine, added an extra 1/4 cup of flour, added a 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg and froze the dough for about half an hour before baking for exactly 9 minutes.  The dough wasn't sticky at all! And the cookies came out perfectly. So soft and chewy in the middle and sweet and crunchy on the outside. I did mix in a little Sugar in the Raw and cinnamon to the rolling sugar mix. Fantastic!

text:
My family loved these cookies. I was glad that I read the reviews prior to making these, if you want to be able to roll them into balls you need more flour than the recipe calls for, otherwise the dough is very soft and "sticky". The recipe calls for 2 1/4 cups of flour. I added another 3/4 cup as someone had suggested and they were much easier to work with. I will definitely make again...in double batches, they go quick!

Wow. I tripled this recipe to make some for family, and coworkers, and managed to make 88 total. Changes I made:
replaced 1 c flour with whole wheat pastry flour, used 1 T ginger, 1/2 t salt, added 1/4 t finely ground black pepper, used 1/2 c butter substitute, used 1/2 c white sugar and 1/2 c dark brown sugar.

Also since I was making these for valetines day I rolled them in red coloured sugar.

I divided the finished dough in 1/2 and refrigerated over night. 

I think next time I will add the ginger in the measurement given in the recipe- I ginger flavor over powering- but thats my bad. Overall a good recipe but I think I will try this baking technique with my favourite gingerbread man recipe.

LOVED these cookies! My husband who's not a fan of ginger cookies ate half the batch. Unlike several others I didn't have any problems with gooey or messiness (I didn't change the recipe at all). In fact, mine were less sticky then choc.chip cookie dough! After making the dough into balls I filled a bowl half full of suger to roll them around and put them on a sheet without flattening them. (more suger coating, and a puffier thicker cookie) I read the recipe wrong and didn't check on them until after 10 minutes. They were STILL moist and soft! And still delicious 4 days later. Next time I may add some choc chips for fun. Thanks for the great recipe!!
